bibl.title: Letter from George A. Bennett to Philip Showalter Hench, November 25, 1952

div1.p: Bennett informs Hench that a representative of Jefferson Medical College will lay a wreath in memory of Finlay at the Camp Lazear dedication. Jefferson Medical College, Finlay's alma mater, is planning a celebration of the centennial of Finlay's graduation, in 1855.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Bennett to Philip Showalter Hench, November 25, 1952
div1.opener:
THE JEFFERSON MEDICAL COLLEGE
AND
MEDICAL CENTER
PHILADELPHIA 7, PA.
November 25, 1952
JEFFERSON MEDICAL COLLEGE
DANIEL BAUGH INSTITUTE OF ANATOMY
THROUGH AFFILIATION
FIFE-HAMILL MEMORIAL HEALTH CENTER
GERMANTOWN DISPENSARY AND HOSPITAL
METHODIST EPISCOPAL HOSPITAL
JEFFERSON MEDICAL COLLEGE HOSPITAL
CURTIS OUTPATIENT CLINIC
DEPARTMENT FOR DISEASES OF THE CHEST
BARTON MEMORIAL HOSPITAL
WHITE HAVEN SANATORIUM (POCONOS)
JEFFERSON HOSPITAL SCHOOL OF NURSING
CHARLOTTE DRAKE CARDEZA FOUNDATION
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
1025 WALNUT STREET
AIRMAIL
(Copy to follow by regular mail)
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your letter of November 18,
concerning the memorializing by the Cuban Government on December
3rd of Walter Reed's Camp Lazear, and your suggestions about the
participation by Jefferson Medical College in the ceremony.

Our College takes much pride in the contributions
made to the control of yellow fever by her graduate, Juan Carlos
Finlay, M. D. Your very interesting article, enclosed with your
letter, adds much to the knowledge we have here about the work of
Walter Reed's Commission and the circumstances under which he ex-
amined the theories and experiments of Doctor Finlay.

We are aware of the regard in which Doctor Finlay is
held by Latin Americans and conscious of the lack of knowledge in
this country concerning his very important service in this medical
problem. We have established a Faculty Committee for the 100th
Anniversary Celebration of Doctor Finlay's graduation from our
medical college in 1855.

Jefferson Medical College would like very much to
participate in the ceremonies on December 3rd. It is uncertain today
whether we shall be able to send a representative from here, in
addition to delegating an alumnus in Havana to represent us. In any
event we shall plan on a College representative attending the ceremony
and placing the wreath under the medallion for Doctor Finlay.

I am turning this matter and your letter over to
our Director of Development and Public Relations, Mr. Paul F. Rake, who
will write you promptly and begin making the necessary arrangements.

We appreciate very much your interest in this period
of medical history and your initiative in according proper recognition
to the men who played important parts in it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Bennett, M. D.
Dean k
